International Tributes to the History of Flight
First International Air Meet
The sport of flying came of age on August 22, 1909,
when a giant air meet was staged in France. For the
first time, the finest pilots and planes from Europe
and America were assembled in one place to compete.
The "La Grande Semaine d'Aviation de la Cham-
pagne" was held on the plains of Bethany, three miles
north of Reims. Leaders from many nations and a
half-million spectators watched about 30 planes com-
pete in races, altitude, and long-distance contests.
America's Glenn Curtiss won the coveted speed race
in an aircraft of his own design. The prize for altitude
(508.5 feet) went to Frenchman Hubert Latham, while
another Frenchman, Henri Farman, won the distance
prize (112 miles).
The full-color cachet shows the poster advertising
the aviation meet and the 200,000-franc Grand Prix
event which Curtiss won with speeds of 47.65 miles
per hour for the two laps. Most of the financing for
the week-long meet came from local champagne
vintners.
Mint Stamp: The mint stamp on this Cover was issued
by the United States in 1980. It pictures Glenn Cur-
tiss, America's official entry at Reims, and a plane
similar to the one he flew in the competitions.
Postmark: This Cover was postmarked in Reims, France
on August 22, 1985, the 75th anniversary of the begin-
ning of the first international air meet.
© Postal Commemorative Society
Printed in U.S.A.
W015. 056.014
properties.sfomuseum:description: Airmail flight cover, part of International Tributes to the History of Flight series by the Postal Commemorative Society; white envelope with full color illustration cachet and inset stamp commemorating first/inaugural international air meet on August 22, 1909, in Reims, France; commemorative cancellation stamp dated August 22, 1985 in Reims; includes information on reverse.
